importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Daniel Naroditsky died on Monday, October 20, 2025, at the age of 29, marking a significant and unexpected loss in the chess community.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: Naroditsky's career spanned from his early achievements in 2007 (winning the Under 12 world championship) through his college years and professional coaching in the 2010s and early 2020s.

keyTakeAways: Daniel Naroditsky, an American chess grandmaster, died at the age of 29 in October 2025.
He was born in San Mateo County, California, to Jewish immigrants from Ukraine and Azerbaijan.
Naroditsky became a grandmaster at age 18 and was known for his expertise in both traditional and blitz chess, maintaining a top 25 ranking in blitz chess for much of his adult career.
He won the U.S. National Blitz Championship in August 2025, his most recent major title.
He played a key role in popularizing chess through live streaming on platforms like YouTube and Twitch, making the game more accessible and educational to a global audience.
Naroditsky was praised by fellow grandmasters such as Hikaru Nakamura and Benjamin Bok for his passion, teaching style, and friendship.
He studied history at Stanford University and earned a bachelor's degree in 2019.
After college, he moved to Charlotte, North Carolina, where he coached junior players at the Charlotte Chess Center.
The cause of his death was not immediately known.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Daniel Naroditsky is central to the article as the subject of the news—his death at 29 marks the main event, and the article details his achievements, contributions, and impact on the global chess community.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Daniel Naroditsky, a renowned American chess grandmaster born in San Mateo County, California, died at age 29 in October 2025. A child prodigy who won the Under 12 world championship in 2007, Naroditsky rose to become a top-ranked player in both traditional and blitz chess, maintaining a top 25 blitz ranking throughout his career. He earned a bachelor's degree in history from Stanford University and later coached at the Charlotte Chess Center in North Carolina. Naroditsky gained global recognition for his live-streamed chess matches on platforms like YouTube and Twitch, where he emphasized education and accessibility, inspiring a new generation of fans. Fellow grandmasters, including Hikaru Nakamura and Benjamin Bok, praised his passion and contributions. The cause of his death remains unknown.
title: American chess grandmaster Daniel Naroditsky dies at 29
